awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Neurotechnologies to Help the Body Move, Heal, and Feel Again
awd_abstract_narration:
This new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award at the University of Houston (UH) will establish a REU Site focused on "Neurotechnologies to Help the Body Move, Heal, and Feel Again." This Site will inspire participants to pursue, with confidence, graduate education and future engineering careers with technical leadership. The REU site will pair 12 undergraduates per summer with faculty mentors from the multi-disciplinary Industry-University Collaborative Research Center for Building Reliable Advances and Innovations in Neurotechnology (IUCRC BRAIN) at the Cullen College of Engineering, for a 10-week research and educational experience in the field of neural, cognitive and rehabilitation engineering. The REU Site addresses society's current critical needs for the aging and disabled populations, leverages current research strengths in the IUCRC BRAIN, and is expected to resonate with undergraduate students and the general public, who have a rising awareness of healthcare and innovative health management devices and are interested in addressing the growing national need for effective management of chronic diseases in the aging population. Thus, this site will give students an opportunity to contribute to the development of safe, effective and affordable personalized neurotechnologies for diagnostics, restoration, enhancement, and rehabilitation of sensory, motor, affective, and cognitive functions. This goal will be pursued by supporting innovative interdisciplinary research across the multiple dimensions of brain function and behavior with the ultimate goal of improving the national health in an inclusive environment that promotes the active participation of underrepresented groups. 

The program is led by an outstanding group of nationally recognized faculty mentors from the University of Houston's Industry-University Collaborative Research Center for Building Reliable Advances and Innovations in Neurotechnology (IUCRC BRAIN) to guide undergraduates in addressing grand challenges in neural, cognitive, and rehabilitation engineering. The goal of the REU is to excite, inspire, train, and nurture future undergraduates and to provide research experiences in multidisciplinary projects with clear societal impact to students who might not otherwise have opportunities for research experiences at their own institutions. The site will actively recruit students underrepresented in STEM fields and from non-research institutions. At the end of their REU experience, students will understand the societal impact of engineering, develop research laboratory skills and good engineering practices, obtain hands-on training in research tools, cultivate soft skills, learn about innovation and entrepreneurship in engineering, and participate in social activities that promote a collegial and collaborative atmosphere among student participants, while learning about the community. Research areas will include device development, neural activity measurement, big data, neuromodulation, neurorehabilitation and assistive devices, device interoperability, and human subjects trials. The ultimate goal of this REU site is to advance the national health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

The overall objective of the REU Site was to inspire diverse participants to pursue, with confidence, graduate education and future engineering careers while addressing some of the grand challenges posed by the National Academy of Engineering (engineer the tools of scientific discovery, reverse engineer the brain, and enhance virtual reality) and the Brain Initiative (Brain Research through Advancing Innovative Neurotechnologies). Project Outcomes were realized in four areas: 

Engineering innovative neurotechnology: Participants were embedded in multi-disciplinary research teams designing and validating innovative neurotechnologies and medical devices. The program theme of ?Neurotechnologies to Help the Body Move, Heal, and Feel Again? addressed society?s current critical needs for disabled populations and other minority groups, leveraged research strengths of a national center (IUCRC BRAIN), and resonated with high-school and undergraduate students, who have a rising awareness of healthcare and innovative health management and are interested in addressing the growing national need for effective management of chronic diseases, physical disabilities, and neurological disorders in the aging population.

Workforce development: The second outcome is the training of a workforce of young pre-engineers and scientists, from pre-college to college levels, in order to maintain American strategic leadership in the neurotechnology field.  The program recruited and trained diverse high school and undergraduate students, empowering them to begin the process of becoming independent researchers while understanding the ethical and responsible use of neurotechnologies, and their potential impact on society. An unexpected outcome of the program in the last two years was the successful transformation to a full virtual (online) experience for all participants due to the pandemic. Several students co-authored publications, won best student paper awards, or received national recognition. This included two who were named Emerging Researchers at the 2020 NSF-AAAS Emergent Researchers National Conference in STEM in Washington DC, one that won third place in the 2021 Health Sciences section at the Kentucky Academy of Science meeting, and one that was selected to present at the Council on Undergraduate Research?s Symposium: Research Experiences for Undergraduates Symposium.

Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion:  The REU program operated at the University of Houston, a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution by the U.S. Department of Education Office of Postsecondary Education, recruited a diverse group of students from under-represented groups in science and engineering, and engaged the diverse community in the Greater Houston Metropolitan Area.  In the four-year program, a total of 63 participants from 37 universities were selected from among a pool of 311 applicants (20% acceptance rate) from across the country. Moreover, our program trained 21 high-school students. Approximately 45% of the REU participants identified themselves as an ethnic minority, and 62% were female, reflecting a diverse demographic that broadens participation from under-represented groups.

Outreach and public engagement: Students participated in outreach activities that engaged the public, including children, by conducting research and innovative science education at Houston?s area museums prior to the pandemic.
